Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technicians and specialists are needed in order to fulfill the demand of the precision agriculture industry as precision agriculture technicians, crop specialists, nutrient management specialists, precision agronomists, service technicians, and research scientists. They work with soil testing companies, crop consulting firms, and fertilizer and chemical retailers, but the shortage of precision agriculture educational opportunities limits the ability of businesses to hire qualified employees and forces them to use their limited resources on incumbent worker training. In addition, the gap between industry need and existing training leads to graduates having to retrain or take additional courses even though they have already earned a general agriculture degree. By offering an enhanced curriculum to high school and college students, this project at Parkland College in Illinois will educate a wide variety of agriculture workers in line with industry needs as it provides a robust education and training program to support the vital agricultural industry of Illinois and the United States. A focus of the project is on increasing the number of women in precision agriculture, which will strengthen and diversify an emerging American industry. The deliverables and best practices developed through the project will be disseminated through coordination with the ATE National Geospatial Technology Center of Excellence, Clark State Community College in Springfield, OH, and agricultural education conferences.

Jobs in precision agriculture require a unique combination of technical and agricultural expertise that is not widely available for high school and college students. Due to the highly technical nature of precision agriculture jobs, the curriculum in the field is often outdated and does not fully prepare students for available positions. Enhancing precision agriculture curriculum for two-year colleges and connecting this curriculum with high schools and four-year colleges will dramatically improve the preparedness of technicians in a number of agricultural sectors. It will utilize the existing precision agriculture curriculum as the foundation for an enhanced program including a more comprehensive associate degree, updated articulation agreements, and the development of dual-enrollment content for area high schools. These components will create a 2+2+2 structure that will be replicable in other regions and sustainable. The project will utilize emerging technologies in conjunction with agronomy to enhance precision agriculture education and will be developed in close partnership with local and regional employers. A formative and summative evaluation process will be employed to continuously enhance the project activities and provide opportunities for researching and evaluating the success of the project and deliverables.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided funding for Parkland College to focus on precision agriculture education to meet the growing demands of the U.S. agriculture industry. The major goals of the grant included: 1) improve and expand precision agriculture education at two-year colleges and 2) improve and expand precision agriculture education opportunities at area high schools and 3) improve compatibility between two-year college and 4-year university precision agriculture curriculum. The investment made in this project has had a demonstrable impact in strengthening precision agriculture curriculum, enrollment numbers and outreach to the secondary education level.

Goal 1:  Improve and expand precision agriculture education at two-year colleges

Department of Labor considers Precision Agriculture Technician employment to consist of a bright outlook (expected rapid growth over the next 10 years that is faster than average growth of jobs). The grant team was able to update and create additional precision agriculture courses to meet the educational requirements for the growing demand of Precision Agriculture Technicians.  Tasks and technology skills as outlined by the Department of Labor for Precision Ag Technicians (source: Department of Labor website ? Precision Ag Technician https://www.onetonline.org/link/summary/19-4099.02) now match Parkland?s Precision Agriculture updated curriculum, new degree requirements and newly created fast-track Precision Agriculture certificate as supported by the industry advisory board. Updated curriculum and the newly created certificate provides students with the opportunity to earn the credential to become commercial drone pilots, incorporates ArcGIS online to better support remote learning as well as incorporation of UAS simulators for practical flying. 

Goal 2:  Improve and expand precision agriculture education opportunities at area high schools

The grant team discovered the potential lack of precision agriculture career awareness in the high school student population through administered surveys to high school students. An overwhelming response of students surveyed indicated over 75% of the respondents had no prior knowledge of Precision Agriculture. Parkland College developed a strategy to address the lack of awareness of Precision Ag Technician career and degree opportunities through the creation of a high school precision agriculture course (Introduction to Precision Agriculture).  The course is offered through Parkland College or at the secondary school level for college credit. Workshops and professional development events were offered to provide training to high school teachers for precision agriculture.  These workshops indicate successful patterns with STEM faculty being able to integrate Precision Agriculture curriculum into the high schools. The grant team demonstrated a pathway to create sustainable, increases in enrollment to support the growing demand of Precision Ag Technicians through this new Introduction to Precision Agriculture course.  

Goal 3:  Improve compatibility between two-year college and 4-year university precision agriculture curriculum

Parkland College officially began articulating precision agriculture courses with the University of Illinois Crop Sciences and Technical Systems Management (TSM) programs.  Students enrolled at the University of Illinois can enroll in Parkland?s Precision Agriculture certificate and earn elective credit toward their Crop Science or TSM degree.  The industry advisory board promoted this partnership to continue to meet the demands of Precision Agriculture Technicians where 4-year degrees were preferred but lacked precision agriculture experience. The articulated courses between Parkland College Precision Agriculture courses and University of Illinois electives are publically available on Transferoloy.com (common public source of articulated courses between colleges and universities). 

 


Last Modified: 03/05/2021
Modified by: Jenni Fridgen
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This award provided funding for Parkland College to focus on precision agriculture education to meet the growing demands of the U.S. agriculture industry. The major goals of the grant included: 1) improve and expand precision agriculture education at two-year colleges and 2) improve and expand precision agriculture education opportunities at area high schools and 3) improve compatibility between two-year college and 4-year university precision agriculture curriculum. The investment made in this project has had a demonstrable impact in strengthening precision agriculture curriculum, enrollment numbers and outreach to the secondary education level. Goal 1: Improve and expand precision agriculture education at two-year colleges Department of Labor considers Precision Agriculture Technician employment to consist of a bright outlook (expected rapid growth over the next 10 years that is faster than average growth of jobs). The grant team was able to update and create additional precision agriculture courses to meet the educational requirements for the growing demand of Precision Agriculture Technicians. Tasks and technology skills as outlined by the Department of Labor for Precision Ag Technicians (source: Department of Labor website ? Precision Ag Technician https://www.onetonline.org/link/summary/19-4099.02) now match Parkland?s Precision Agriculture updated curriculum, new degree requirements and newly created fast-track Precision Agriculture certificate as supported by the industry advisory board. Updated curriculum and the newly created certificate provides students with the opportunity to earn the credential to become commercial drone pilots, incorporates ArcGIS online to better support remote learning as well as incorporation of UAS simulators for practical flying. Workshops and professional development events were offered to provide training to high school teachers for precision agriculture. The grant team demonstrated a pathway to create sustainable, increases in enrollment to support the growing demand of Precision Ag Technicians through this new Introduction to Precision Agriculture course. The articulated courses between Parkland College Precision Agriculture courses and University of Illinois electives are publically available on Transferoloy.com (common public source of articulated courses between colleges and universities).
